newsitem.title: USA: Caterpillar will meet with UAW.
newsitem.headline: Caterpillar will meet with UAW.

text.p: Caterpillar Inc. said Thursday it will meet Oct. 7 with the United Auto Workers union on the subject of employee firings and will not impose employment terms on Oct. 1 as previously planned.
Caterpillar had said in August that it believed it was at an impasse with the union over employee discharges.
The company had said it was prepared to unilaterally impose a series of employment terms at its eight U.S. plants represented by the UAW on Oct. 1.
In a statement, Caterpillar Vice President Wayne Zimmerman said the company remains unwilling to grant amnesty or arbitration for employees fired before the end of a 17-month strike in December.
Caterpillar has said it is willing to offer arbitration for employees fired after the strike, which ended without a new contract.
The company's UAW members have been working without a contract since 1991.

"We don't know if the union has changed its position on discharges, or whether a meeting will be productive," Wayne Zimmerman, vice president of the construction, mining and power generation equipment maker said.
A union spokesman could not immediately be reached for comment.
